Golay's daughter is not on trial for the murder, but the jury will soon decide the faith of her mother and her mother's alleged partner - Two septuagenarians who face the rest of their lives behind bars if they're convicted.
Mandalit del Barco, NPR News.
It's Saturday and it's August.
Do you know where your member of Congress is?
Believe it or not, he or she may be at the House of Representatives, which is meeting even as we speak.
The Senate started its summer recess last night.
The House is expected to follow suit tonight or early tomorrow morning.
NPR congressional correspondent Andrea Seabrook is following the last-minute legislative frenzy.
And hello, Andrea.
How are you, Jacki?
I guess not just the streets of Washington are boiling over today but the atmosphere in the House is pretty hot as well?
It is.
Jacki, it's pretty much partisan insanity.
I mean, actually, Republicans have been throwing legislative grenades for several days, anything to throw a wrench in the works.
For example, coming in this Saturday morning, 9:00 a.m., the very first thing the House did was vote on a Republican motion to adjourn.
It's just been crazy.
And the whole political fight here is really over what will be said about this Congress.
Democrats want to go home, tell their constituents about all the hard work they've done.
Republicans want to show just how messy the House has been under the Democratic majority.
So in that atmosphere, did they get anything done?
In fact, they have been working most of the day on an energy bill that focuses, for the first time, on conservation rather than new oil and natural gas drilling.
It puts new higher efficiency standards in place for everything from federal buildings down to light bulbs.
It will spark new ethanol production from corn and other crops.
And it pays for all of these by, in fact, revoking many of the tax breaks Republicans passed in recent years for big oil and natural gas companies.
That is Congresswoman Lois Frankel.
She's a Democrat.
She represents Florida's 21st District.
That's in Southern Florida.
Which is - yeah, the Muslims' prayers day.
And there was calls for all Egyptians to come out tomorrow.
It must be very emotional for you to watch these images coming out of your country and where your family and so many of your friends, I'm sure, are still are.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I mean, I'm not only that, Mary Louise.
It's - I will speak freely.
I love NPR.
I'm a big fan of your programs.
So thank you, first, for the opportunity to talk with you and with your audience.
This is probably a very unique experience for me.
I mean, it's like a rollercoaster ride.
And the first three, four days, I felt really tall.
I felt very proud of what these young kids are doing in the streets.
I never thought I'll see this in my lifetime.
Their courage, their civility, their way of saying enough is enough, captured all the attentions and made me very, very proud of what they are doing.
Then comes yesterday, and seeing this horrible scenes, I mean, riding horses and camels?
Who directed this scene, right, and the violence and the - it's just - so I can tell you I didn't sleep a minute last night.
So it's rollercoaster.
It's sad.
It's overwhelming to see that we, America, that all the civilized world have supported this ruthless government for so long.
And it's time now, to take the right side of history and support the people that are calling for their freedom, for democracy, for their dignity.
Okay.
We have a caller on the line.

Hi, Baheera.
Hi.
How are you?
Hi.
Great.
How are you?
I'm fine.
Thanks.
I'm actually very disturbed, as you can imagine.
Sure.
Are you a - let me ask your background.
Are you Egyptian American?
Yes, I am.
And what are you watching as you watch events unfold in Egypt?
What kind of things are you looking for?

I mean, to be honest with you, this whole process started with a tremendous amount of hope on the parts of everyone, because here were these people that are managing to stand up and, you know, they have this amazing goal of democracy, and they were completely peaceful.

And I think the most troubling part is that the government, rather than stepping down and listening to the people and their legitimate desires, chose to send in hired thugs, or whatever you want to call them.
It's unfortunate that they're being called pro-Mubarak demonstrators.

And it was when they were sent in with weapons that all the violence began and, unfortunately, it's giving a completely wrong impression of something that started peacefully and with, you know, tremendous amount of dignity, a tremendous amount of hope.
And one person's reluctance to step down is resulting in a massacre in the country.
And people are, you know, they're on the verge of civil war, if you could even call it that.
I don't know.
It's paid operatives versus, you know, peaceful protesters at this point, trying to defend themselves in any way that they can.
And it's just - it's extremely, extremely disturbing for us that have a family there, that have, you know, aspirations for Egypt as a country to prosper under democratic rule.
Well, I was going to ask you...
We just don't know what to make of it.
Do you have people there who you're particularly worried about, who you're trying to stay in contact with yourself, Baheera?
Of course, of course.
I have many friends and I have many family members.
And, you know, what's happened is they've managed to turn public opinion around because people are now worried about their safety.
You know, these pro-Mubarak thugs have managed to put insecurity and fear in people.
One, people are staying home because they're afraid for their safety and the safety of their families.
They don't want to leave their families behind.

There are prisoners that have been set free from prisons, and it's still - the verdict is out if they're - you know, if that was just spontaneous or if they were actually intentionally released to wreak havoc on the country and to convince individuals that they will be safer under the rule of Mubarak, despite the oppression and corruption, than to let this process continue.
And it's just extremely troubling because, you know, one man's reluctance is resulting in so much damage.
I mean, people are dying.
People are dying.
It's an extremely serious situation.
And as you can see, I mean, they have no interest in this being reported on.

I understand that journalists have been rounded up, and then that's really, really even more concerning because what's going to happen tomorrow that they don't want to be seen, that they don't want to be documented, that they don't want the rest of the world to see, you know?
